clinical_study.brief_title: Therapeutic Controlled Hypothermia in the Treatment of Neonates With Severe Necrotizing Enterocolitis
clinical_study.official_title: Therapeutic Controlled Hypothermia in the Treatment of Neonates With Severe Necrotizing Enterocolitis

lead_sponsor.agency: Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children NHS Foundation Trust

clinical_study.source: Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children NHS Foundation Trust

brief_summary.textblock: Hypothesis: Controlled hypothermia to 33.5C for 48 hours reduces the severity of critical illness in neonates with severe necrotizing enterocolitis.

primary_outcome.measure: Difference in sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) score
primary_outcome.description: Difference in sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) score at 5 days after intervention

secondary_outcome.measure: Baseline time taken to establish full enteral feeds
secondary_outcome.description: Time to establish full enteral feeds and organ functional investigation and biomarkers at baseline, 24 hours post, 63 hours post and day 5 post intervention
Neurodevelopmental outcome with MRI at term corrected age and neurodevelopmental assessment at 3, 6,12 and 24 months and mortality data

arm_group.description: Control group: Standard treatment of care at normothermia
Therapeutic controlled hypothermia (33.5C) using cooling blanket/mattress

intervention.description: Therapeutic controlled hypothermia (33.5C) using cooling blanket/mattress

intervention.description: Standard treatment of care in 33.5C for 48 hours
intervention.arm_group_label: Standard treatment of care at normothermia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- weight at diagnosis > 700 grams
- confirmed NEC (Bell's stage II or III)
- radiological evidence of pneumatosis coli
- systemic compromise as defined by increase in ventilation requirement and/or requiring inotopic support
